Presenting Problem / Chief Complaint: The patient has been managing a busy life with work and children, feeling somewhat overwhelmed but generally okay.
History of Present Illness (HPI): The patient has started supervisory classes, which are challenging due to balancing responsibilities. They experience stress, especially when trying to support their daughter, and are exploring ways to improve communication with her.
Psychosocial History: The patient is actively engaged in their family life and is focused on personal growth through education and mindfulness practices.
Physiological Observations: The patient reports inconsistent sleep patterns, affected by racing thoughts and stress.
Current Functional Status: The patient is attempting to manage their stress through meditation and physical activity but acknowledges inconsistency in their routines.
Progress Evaluation: The patient feels more relaxed after practicing mindfulness techniques and is recognizing the need for better communication with their daughter.
Therapeutic Interventions: The patient is open to practicing active listening techniques and establishing a calming bedtime routine to improve sleep.
Next Steps: The patient plans to spend quality time with their daughter and try a new bedtime routine to enhance relaxation and sleep quality.
